channel.title: NYT > World

item.title: Fireworks Go Wrong at Kerala Temple in Southern India, Killing Many
item.description: A fireworks display during a religious festival at a temple set off a series of explosions, leveling buildings and killing at least 86 people.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND and SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Officials loaded an injured person into an ambulance after explosions at a temple in the southern Indian state of Kerala on Sunday.

item.title: Fire at Temple in Southern India Kills at Least 80
item.description: Hundreds of people were trapped by flames in the Paravoor temple in the city of Kollam early Sunday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: “Officials loaded an injured person into an ambulance following a fire from a fireworks display at a temple in the southern Indian state of Kerala on Sunday.”

item.title: Fighting Kills 18 Soldiers and 5 Militants in Philippines
item.description: The largest single-day combat loss this year for the military comes as the Philippines remembers its World War II dead.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Archbishop of Canterbury Says DNA Test Shows His Father Was Churchill’s Private Secretary
item.description: In frank statements, the Most Rev. Justin Welby, the spiritual leader of 86 million Anglicans, and his mother talked of the shock of discovering the truth in the past month.
item.dc:creator: YONETTE JOSEPH
item.media:description: The Most Rev. Justin Welby after he was installed as the archbishop of Canterbury at Canterbury Cathedral in England in March 2013.

item.title: Harrowing Trip for Chinese Trawler Before Bump in Territorial Tensions
item.description: A trawler’s seizure by Indonesia, part of a continuing dispute in the South China Sea, began with a crew mate’s warning: “A gunboat is coming.”
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and YUFAN HUANG
item.media:description: The Chinese Coast Guard rescued a fishing trawler last month that had been seized by the Indonesian authorities.

item.title: Climate-Related Death of Coral Around World Alarms Scientists
item.description: Researchers believe that bleaching, which they attribute to heat stress compounded by climate change, is threatening more than a third of the planet’s reefs.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: A turtle swimming over bleached coral near Heron Island, in the southern Great Barrier Reef.

item.title: Afghan General Plants Flowers in Helmand, but Taliban Lurk
item.description: Maj. Gen. M. Moein Faqir is the top military man in Helmand Province, more than half of which has been overrun by the Taliban in the past year.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maj. Gen. M. Moein Faqir, the top Afghan military officer in Helmand Province, more than half of which has been overrun by Taliban in the past year.

item.title: Argentine Prosecutor May Add Ex-President to Financial Inquiry
item.description: The decision to include former President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner in a widening investigation into money laundering was made after a financier gave lengthy testimony on Friday, according to the state news agency.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: Argentina's President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner smiles after arriving for the opening session of the 133rd legislative term of Congress in Buenos Aires, March 1, 2015. REUTERS/Marcos Brindicci (ARGENTINA - Tags: POLITICS) NYTCREDIT: Marcos Brindicci/Reuters

item.title: Man in Hat in Brussels Airport Attack Is in Custody, Belgium Says
item.description: Mohamed Abrini, who was detained Friday, confessed he was the suspect seen with two suicide bombers in a surveillance image, the Belgian prosecutor’s office said.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Belgian police officers in Brussels on Saturday.

item.title: In Afghanistan, John Kerry Seeks End to Bickering of Unity Government
item.description: The secretary of state meet with the leaders of the coalition government, which has struggled with infighting and a resurgent Taliban.
item.dc:creator: JAWAD SUKHANYAR and MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry speaking in Kabul on Saturday with Salahuddin Rabbani, Afghanistan’s foreign minister.

item.title: Inside Saudi Arabia’s Re-education Prison for Jihadists
item.description: The Family House feels like a boutique hotel, if you can overlook the lack of windows, the towering walls outside and the location inside a high-security prison.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Austria Considers Law to Seize Home Where Hitler Was Born
item.description: Hitler himself paid no attention to the town of Braunau, but the fate of the privately owned home there has been debated since World War II ended.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adolf Hitler was born in a three-story building in Braunau, Austria. His parents rented an apartment above what was then a tavern.

item.title: As Britain Contemplates Exit, Boris Johnson Prepares His Entrance
item.description: Mr. Johnson, the mayor of London, is bucking his party by supporting Britain’s exit from the European Union, effectively announcing his bid to be prime minister.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Mayor Boris Johnson of London is the highest-profile Tory to have defected from the campaign led by Prime Minister David Cameron to keep Britain inside the European Union.

item.title: Olympus Investigation Shows Ethical Lapses and a Caterer With Clout
item.description: Two years after admitting to accounting fraud, Olympus hired its cafeteria operator to handle a dispute with Chinese customs authorities. Soon after, the case was inexplicably dropped.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Olympus campus in Shenzhen, China. The company hired its cafeteria operator to act as a go-between with the government in a thorny customs case.

item.title: Aung San Suu Kyi Has Cataract Surgery, Her Doctor Says
item.description: The operation, which was successful, will be followed by a second later in April for the Burmese leader’s other eye, the doctor said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi underwent successful cataract surgery on Saturday.

item.title: North Korea Says It Successfully Tested Missile Engine
item.description: An announcement was the latest claim of success in testing various technologies needed to build an intercontinental ballistic missile.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Before and After the Panama Papers: David Cameron of Britain on Tax Avoidance
item.description: The prime minister has condemned offshore accounts used to avoid taxes, but leaked documents show that his family has profited from an offshore investment fund.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Johan Van Steen, Legal Expert and Photographer, Dies in Brussels Attacks
item.description: Mr. Van Steen, 58, was a legal adviser to the Belgian government, but it was his view of the world through the camera’s lens that defined him, his partner says.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Johan Van Steen was killed in a blast at the Maelbeek subway station in Brussels on March 22.

item.title: Catholics Express Hope and Disappointment Over Pope’s Statement on Families
item.description: Francis’ manifesto, “Amoris Laetitia,” is turning out to be a Rorschach test for members of the Church.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:credit: Edmund D. Fountain for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Cardinal Daniel DiNardo, Archbishop of Galveston-Houston, Tex.; Joseph Kurtz, Archbishop of Louisville, Ky.; and Msgr. Ronny Jenkins at the start of the general session of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops in 2014.

item.title: News Analysis: Rather Than Rules, Pope’s Document Gives License to Adapt
item.description: Rather than dictating policy like a chief executive, Pope Francis effectively devolved power on family issues.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Pope Francis at Easter Mass in St. Peter’s Square last month. He issued an apostolic exhortation on family life on Friday.
